Award.AwardTitle: Zeta Functions and the Distribution of Field Discriminants
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will apply the theory of zeta functions associated to prehomogeneous vector spaces to study the distribution of field discriminants. Research on counting field discriminants dates back to 1857 work of Hermite, and is the subject of recent breakthroughs by Bhargava and his collaborators. Bhargava's work is essentially geometric in nature, and the PI will develop an alternative approach, using Shintani zeta functions and analytic number theory. Although the zeta function approach is not new, the PI and his collaborator Takashi Taniguchi have developed a method which circumvents a technical difficulty with this approach. This led to a resolution of a well-known conjecture on cubic fields, among other results. The PI will further develop this method to study related questions, including the distribution of quartic and quintic fields.

Gauss said that "mathematics is the queen of the sciences and number theory is the queen of mathematics." Number theory has inspired and spurred on the development of many areas of mathematics, and has also seen practical applications, for example in cryptography. Number fields are a foundational object of study in algebraic number theory, which explains the strong interest in studying their discriminants. In contrast, Shintani's theory of zeta functions seems to have received inadequate attention, especially outside Japan. The PI's work will further develop Shintani's theory, with an eye towards solving open problems of broader current interest, and it will also help to bring an active area of Japanese mathematics to the attention of researchers in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project saw the PI make substantial developments to the theory of arithmetic statistics: questions concerning the distribution of number field discriminants, elements of class groups of number fields, elements of Selmer groups of elliptic curves, and so forth.

 

This is currently a very popular and fruitful area of research: Manjul Bhargava recently won the Fields Medal for his work in the subject. For the most part, Bhargava and his collaborators have worked on two families of problems: (1) prove "parametrization theorems" that establish that arithmetic objects correspond to lattice points in certain "fundamental domains" in various spaces; (2) refine "geometry of numbers" techniques needed to actually count these lattice points.

 

The PI has worked on a variety of methods that complement (but do not duplicate) those of Bhargava and others. One such is through the use of Shintani zeta functions: certain analytic functions that also describe the distribution of these same lattice points. Informally, one might regard these zeta functions as oracles that know the answer to any possible question concerning their distribution. The difficulty is that these oracles' language is difficult to speak and interpret. In any case, there remain many unsolved problems concerning these zeta functions, and the PI will continue to work to address them.

 

The PI also engaged in an extended collaboration with Henri Cohen, to develop the use of Kummer theory and class field theory -- again, to count arithmetic objects. The theorems we developed are of a different flavor: we can describe the distribution much more precisely, if we restrict to one "resolvent field" at a time. These results are interesting on their own, and also combine with Shintani's theory in interesting ways. For example, the PI proved that Shintani's zeta functions cannot be written as a finite sum of Euler products.

 

Another project that the PI took on was the study of "singular exponential sums" associated to the underlying "prehomogeneous vector spaces". The PI encountered this in his first serious paper on the subject, and studied them by laborious ad hoc methods. But recently he and his collaborator Takashi Taniguchi realized that they enjoy a lot of structure, and developed and implemented a program for evaluating them in a lot of cases. These results should prove useful in our future work, as well as (we believe) that of Bhargava and anyone else who works on the same sorts of questions.

 

NSF funding also helped to greatly expand the research seminars at the University of South Carolina. The PI used these funds to bring a number of outstanding speakers to campus to speak in our research seminars. This has helped to expose our students and faculty to a broad range of contemporary research, and it has established a seminar culture at USC. Our first algebra seminar of the year attracted an audience of eighteen, much larger than the seminar audiences when the PI first began his appointment five years ago. The PI's impression is that the quality of our department is on a definite upswing. The PI (among many others) have worked to make this possible, and NSF funding has been vital towards this end.
